segments.text: Well, this issue first came up in about 57 or 58 in a discussion with a gentleman who was then vice president of Duke, but running it, because the president at that point didn't do much.
His name was Paul M. Gross.
And Paul was president of AAAS.
He was an advisor to Eisenhower, chemist, really a sharp guy.
At that time, it must have been, oh, in his 60s,
suppress a few chuckles about it.
Sitting next to him during that first discussion as to the possibilities of my appointment to the department was a man who was the provost of the university.
And the provost got his degree at Duke University as a student of Paul Grove.
And when the chairman of the department, who at that time
very opposed to it, made a snide remark about inbreeding.
I saw these two gentlemen take a little twinkle.
I found it very amusing.
And apparently, Paul didn't think of any great risk involved.
The next series of questions I have to ask now have to do with what you conceive of the role of oceanography to be in the future.
futuristic questions.
Those questions scientists like the least to answer.
First of all, as an administrator and scientist, what sort of topics in oceanography do you think will be the so-called hot topics of the future for which students to operate on?
Scientifically.
Scientifically.
That is, if nuclear physics, for example, was the hot topic of the 50s for oceanographers, which...
disciplines of oceanography are now in ascendance and which are in decline.

Well, biological oceanography has always been pretty far down on the list, in part because of the nature of the people who work in it, and in part because it does not provide a direct link to economic development and the gross national product, which the geological crowd do.
And the military have supported, say, physical oceanography because of their own interests, especially in the realm of the Navy, which is fine.
That's their business.
I think we have finished or are finishing what might be construed as a survey period.
We have amassed unbelievable amounts
there, but primarily what is there.

And now I will not be at all surprised to see a greater emphasis on subdivisions of why is the animal there, what permits it to live and reproduce there, how did it get there in the first place, and what does it do there.
to begin to look into that and then within that I'm sure we will see a variety of assaults or little forays out into the beyond the frontier on
far more molecular questions as to are there common denominators among certain marine forms that permit them to do similar things.
And this is coming from thoughts about marine fouling, for example.
Is it possible to find a common biochemical denominator that would answer some of the questions of fouling and provide us with a mechanism for controlling it?
For years, the Navy has put all sorts of money into anti-fouling paints where you dump compound A into paint.
If that doesn't work, you try B.
You don't really know why you try B, but somebody thinks it's a good idea.
And you can do that ad nauseum at the rate at which the chemical industry is developing compounds, but it's a rather empirical approach which hasn't produced any really good results.
So I think we will see more and more effort in that particular realm in looking at the regulatory mechanisms
live within a particular environment?
What are the clues that they get, like in the old problem of vertical migration and the scattering layer?
What tells the animals to do what they do?
And now you're getting into a whole interdisciplinary, managed team research theme.
And I think if IDOE is successful, and I'm not sure how you're going to measure it or who will measure it,

But we will see more emphasis on trying to bring together groups of scientists across disciplinary lines to look at some of the big problems and hopefully leaving the individual scientist to still do his thing.

Because a lot of the real innovative, creative thinking is done by that guy who just sits and thinks about it for a while and comes up with an approach that the team would never come up with as a whole.
Now, specifically, I don't know that I can say.

Second, what technological breakthroughs, if any, do you consider instrumental in changing oceanography, or the discipline of oceanography, or the approach of the discipline of oceanography in the last
Well, outside of biological oceanography, certainly things like side scanning sonar have been major breakthroughs and have given us tools to do things that we could never have done before.
The Alvin gets us into a part of the oceans which we have just explored by wire before.
And I will not be surprised to see a greater interest in
the proper use of submersibles.
I think that they have been considered pretty much of a toy by some people, and the results which have come from them leave much to be desired.
But with the 200-mile limit and a further interest in the seabed and life in the abyssal deeps, I assume that we will go in that direction.
And there certainly is good justification for it, if it's a program that is properly developed.
In the realm of biological oceanography, unfortunately, I'm hard-pressed to point out any real major breakthrough.

Now, you can look at the development of teams as a major breakthrough, because biologists do not normally lend themselves to big team research, but the Quayer group apparently have been able to do this.

And the interrelationships between the chemists, the physicists, and the biologists in that program suggest that under the right conditions, with the right personalities, and the right idiosyncrasies, it can be done.
And it's the only way to answer some of the big problems.
What do you see as the role of systematics in marine biology?
Do you see that declining or increasing?
Well, in reality, I see it as declining, but it's unfortunate.
And we will find out that we were wrong in permitting it to decline.
When all is said and done, you still must know what you're working with, whether you're a chemist working with some organic compound or a biologist working with some animal.
And if you cannot properly identify that, be it a chemical compound or an animal,
Nobody else will know what you're talking about, and you won't either.
So I think we may see, we have seen the bottom of the curve insofar as systematics is concerned.
And I would like to think that we will begin to see renewed emphasis on systematics, perhaps with a slightly different twist.
it'll still serve the same function, to be able to identify animals and relate them to the rest of the animal kingdom.
And what slightly different twist do you see attached to it?
Anything specific?
Oh, people are already looking at the use of computers and other tools, and there's nothing really new about it.
What about the impact of computer data on such things as physical oceanography?

It has been suggested that computer data will soon eliminate that great age of exploration, that is, of... No, I think it'll just give us a better focus, because before we've been, well, like the title of the U.S.-Soviet thing, of the world's oceans, we've been trying to look at the whole ocean, which is ridiculous.

A number of recent discoveries off here point out quite conclusively that there are all sorts of far more localized phenomena that deserve attention before we can begin to put them all together as pieces representing the dynamics of the oceans.
It has also been suggested, too, that new 200-mile limits, new international pressures,
may turn people back once more to the coastal shelves, the geographic entities which were not too popular among biologists, marine biologists and oceanographers in decades past.
Would you agree with that?
Yeah, but I would add one other motivating force, and that is politics and support.
we saw in the middle of the 60s the beginning of a trend on the part of the Congress which said, in essence, you guys have gotten all this money.
Now what do you do with it other than figure out that the oceans are deep and that there's something living at the bottom?
What's that got to do with us?
And I will not be at all surprised if we see a greater emphasis on the part of the funding agencies

the research that has been deep ocean, moving in toward land where it has some connection with the real world that the congressman can understand and that may have a direct bearing on the country which is providing the support.
And I don't object to that at all.
And that was the next question.
Do you think the return to coastal water is particularly good?
Now, you said earlier in the interview that, in effect, it was coastal waters which produced the most of what man needs.

Do you think the economic crunch, now allow me to say that, is the fuel crisis, the energy shortage, and the food crisis all will turn us back more to coastal waters and oceanography and away from deep water activity?
Yeah, I just hope that it's
not a complete turnaround, because there's still an awful lot that we need to know about deep oceans.
And it would be a real disaster if an ultimatum were to come out tomorrow saying that, henceforth, you could only work within 300 meters or something.
And all too frequently, this is what happens, that when the pendulum swings, it goes crunch.
It doesn't swing just 2 thirds of the way.
There are very definite needs in the coastal waters, and they will not be resolved if all of us are out looking 5,000 meters.
Now, several things on which I'd like a quick opinion on from you.
Mining the ocean floors, that is, the ocean excluding coastal waters as a source of minerals for mankind.
Are you optimistic or not optimistic?
You said excluding coastal waters.
Excluding coastal waters.
The second question is coastal waters.
First excluding coastal waters, then coastal waters.
Well, I don't know that as the technology is presently developed, we have, with the exception of oil, the machinery to mine the deep oceans.
Now, 10 years from now, we may.
But it's going to have to be something that is really in short supply before the economics of it will make it feasible.
It's like mining the moon.
Presumably, we can do that too if we want to, but can you afford anything that comes off of it?
Now, coastal waters, very definitely.
And to me, it's a matter of real concern in this state, for example.
We know that sizable phosphate deposits are located under coastal waters, which are the property of the state of North Carolina held in trust for the citizens of the state.
The efforts thus far toward phosphate mining in particular have been very, well, they have resulted in deleterious effects to the environment.
And I'm trying to encourage the state to take the OPEC attitude toward phosphates under the coastal waters.
That if somebody really wants it, they can pay for it.
But it is a non-renewable resource.
And that provision should be made to reimburse the citizens of this state and replace the estuaries that they will tear up in the process of mining.
But nobody cares about that yet.
They will.
But it's quite feasible, and it's right down the road, there's no doubt about it.
Okay.
Besides phosphates and oil, which are all accurately named, can you think of other mineral resources which will be available off the coastal shores?
Oh, the chances are good it's like everything else.
Thus far, our efforts have been expended largely toward oil and phosphate.
And in looking for them, we've most likely overlooked a variety of other things.
And if we find other things, which there's no reason why we shouldn't,
then again, if it's economically feasible and profitable, people will begin to develop the techniques to mine them.
What about plankton and kelp?
These are two words that appear frequently in the vocabulary of the 60s in terms of potential food sources and other valuable resources.
A comment on those?
Well, on the East Coast, of course,
and will undoubtedly provide a number of things that will be useful, but I don't know on what scale.
Plankton, directly, no.
This is, well, it's a little too far down on the food chain to make it worthwhile in the, well, if you look at a whale,
in order to pick up the plankton necessary to sustain it.
And I would not advocate that we develop a mechanical whale to do this, because the energy expended in driving the whale would far exceed the return in terms of the plankton.
Now, finally, do you feel as if, or in your opinion, let me say this, in your opinion,
Has the glory years of oceanography peaked?
That is, the number of people enrolled in schools, the number of supports going to receive from federal agencies.
Is that a thing of the past?
No, I don't think so.
I think it's, like everything else in this world, it's a cycle.
And for years, politicians and biopoliticians
have been talking about the 70% of the Earth's globe is covered with the oceans and what it can mean to the future of civilization.
And it's sort of a pretty well worn out phrase, but it's still true.
And I think with the 200 mile limit and a variety of other political developments, we're going to see a long term interest in the oceans.
And there will continue to be varying demands on numbers of oceanographers and for numbers of oceanographers.
I think that we may have seen an end to the period of exploration for purely academic reasons, as we know it.
But we will see more and more emphasis on utilization of the ocean.
to me a relatively young science, one of the few that is truly international and has been since it was first conceived.
And this, to me, will be the thing that will sustain it.
Now, what about the picture collection?
Okay.
Gunnar Thorsen, for many years, carried with him a movie camera.
And any place he was in a group of more than three scientists, he proceeded to take a 30-second shot of individuals in the group.
And he left his widow a sizable collection of film that involves big names in the realm of European
and others who are oceanographers.
It would include a lot of oceanographers.
And that film, to my knowledge, just sits.
I wrote her and asked her if there were any plans for any kind of editing and, you know, the release of some sort of a 30-minute film of oceanographers or something.
She said she had turned it over, I think, to the University of Copenhagen and kept a copy for herself.

But it would be a shame to let something like that just sit when a group like yours might be able to get a copy of it and develop it with a little technical assistance, perhaps, into a really good documentary film of trends in oceanography since World War II or something like that.
Because it would include a lot of people who are now gone.
It surely would.
Including Gunnar himself.
I assume he's on there.
I don't know how he did his own picture.
But there are a good number of people, of course, very important oceanography have died in the last four years.
And he covered the globe more than any other man for his time.
He was involved in the development of the Thai-Danish cooperative program.
He was down there talking about the Suez Canal and a cooperative study of the Suez Canal between
all sorts of people years ago.
I mean, it was amazing what that guy did with a lot of help from people like F.G. Walton and Hilary Moore and Kenna and all over the place.
But if you ever get an interest in it, let me know, because I knew her, still do, reasonably well.
And I could serve as a catalyst on that front.
I think I'm going to talk to Cal Houn about that.
Nothing else.
Copies of that film ought to be placed in archives like Duke or Texas A&M or someplace so I can afford to put it so that it would be here in this country available later on in the future.
Well, do you have anything else you'd like to say?
Any comments you'd like to make in oceanography and about oceanography in general or anything in particular?
Well, one thing you didn't touch on, which I'm sure you're aware of, but relatively speaking, the oceanographic community is very small.
And I'm convinced that this, coupled with the international aspects of it, have contributed to what little success we may be able to point to.
Because if I drop down in the middle of Hamburg tomorrow, I will meet people I know, who know people I know, who have worked with other people that I know, and who know me and so forth.
And it's really amazing.
at even one of the big oceanographic conferences, how relatively small the number is and how intertwined it all is.
Now, of course, it breaks pretty much into physical, geological, chemical, and biological.
and vice versa.
The geological oceanographers somehow tend to be a little more communicative, in part, I think, because they have mutual needs.
Chemists, some.
But if you go to a meeting of ASZ, there are far more people and far less communication than you have with limnology and oceanography, say, or ASO.
And at some point, it would be interesting just for fun, I think, to see if there is any kind of a relationship between numbers and the communication that we enjoy within the oceanographic community.
I know some of the early relationships between the Soviets and the US were purely coincidence.
A US ship would stop at Dakar.
before Big Brother could realize what was going on, the two communities had gotten together in a pub someplace and were having a drink.
And they were exchanging all sorts of scientific information and agreeing, OK, now next month we're going to be in some place.
We'll see you then.
And a lot of the things that started early in the game between the Soviet Union and the United States started that way.
And it wouldn't have been possible if it hadn't been for the international
nature and spread of facilities such as ships.
No, I wasn't aware of that at all.
And people like Howie Sanders, Woods Hole, knew and talked with Soviet scientists long before the government ever considered that such a thing might be a good idea.
And it goes on all the time.
And now, of course, it's loosely accepted, at least by their government.
But in the old days, it wasn't, and it happened in spite of them.
Which I guess, if you want to take it back into its historical days, is the same sort of thing that has happened traditionally in the seafaring communities.
Apprentices would sneak out of a country by ship someplace and take their
knowledge of the silver trade over to another country and seafaring men would pull into a dock and pick up the latest news of revolution and take it home.
The same sort of thing.
It's a real loose crowd.
It's a pretty independent crowd.
It's a pretty self-starting crowd.
And it's something about the sea, I think, that encourages this.
Now, of course, your discussion today denied this, but my impression certainly was that a growing specialization among oceanographers was tending to break up this community.
Well, I don't see it.
But maybe it's because I'm not as much one of the
Well, I don't consider myself to be on the in-group of the big oceanographic institutions, and it doesn't bother me any.
But it may well be that if you were to talk to people like Paul Fein, Woods Hole, Art Maxwell, and that crap, who are the kingpins of oceanography in a big sense, yeah, they may see it that way.
But I'm sort of standing on the periphery looking at it from a far more overview standpoint than I would expect they would be.
Well, one of the attractions of oceanography was, and then one of the international attractions too, was that oceanographers were an academic discipline, had to have advice from other people.
Right.
Because with a common ground in the ocean, they had to know somebody who could do chemistry.
Even though they might know what chemistry was about, they couldn't do it if they were going to get any help.
And I think you get constant injections of new ideas this way.
You don't get into a rut.
And if the day comes when we do, then we're really in trouble.
But I think there are enough young, independent, on occasion abrasive,
scientists who will not let that happen, and their day will come soon.
